Write to Deepen Comprehension: Personal Response
Have students write about why it is important to support charities that help people in need.
Allow students to orally share with a partner what they want to write before writing.
Prompt them to look back at the story for support in writing.
Students can complete the writing during independent work time.
Read the title, and have students repeat as they point to each word.

, or an organization he believes in. Explain that a
is a place where people can get free food. Ask students to predict what the boys idea might be.
routine. You will prompt students to use this word to talk about the story.

would you be willing to support? Why?

The /ô/ sound transfers or has an approximation in many languages. Notable exceptions are Mandarin, Farsi, and Arabic. The graphemes (spelling patterns) do not transfer, with the exception of a sound-symbol match for au in Haitian Creole.

Practice articulation with a few simple high-utility words and phrases, such as talk, small, saw, pause, water, and I like to draw ____. Model correct mouth position. Then have students copy the words to practice writing the letters and reading words with /ô/ spellings.

Coral Reefs: A Call to Action, pages 811
Apply to Reading and Writing (10 MIN.)
Read: Coral Reefs: A Call to Action
Guide students through a reading of Coral Reefs: A Call to Action.
Write to Deepen Comprehension: Write a List
Have students list three to five facts they learned about coral reefs.
Have them draw a picture to accompany their list.
Read the title, and have students repeat as they point to each word.
Explain that this text is a photo comic. It has panels and text boxes like a comic, but it features photos and facts instead of illustrations and dialogue for a story.
Explain that a coral reef is a large structure under the water made up of sea creatures called corals. Ask students to point to the coral reef on page 8.
routine. You will prompt students to use this word to talk about the story.
the plants and animals that live there.

Find the phrase that tells where divers go to see coral reefs. (into the water)
What is the connection between polyps and coral reefs? Find the sentences that answer the question.
How are the worlds coral reefs being
mean? How can regrowing coral in nurseries help coral reefs that have been damaged?
Why do you think the author included the subtitle A Call to Action? How does the author encourage readers to take action?
What other questions do you have about coral reefs? How could you find answers to them?

Ask students to identify the vowel team spelling for the

(aw). Point out that some vowel teams include the letter w or y, which can be both a consonant (/w/ and /y/ sounds) or a part of a vowel team. These common vowel team spellings include aw, ow, ay, and ey.

Use Supports for Segmenting and Manipulating Sounds
Prompt students to mark the sounds, such as by tapping or using counters, when they need support orally segmenting the word before writing it.
You can also model by moving one colored square or block for each sound or syllable when manipulating (adding, deleting, substituting) sounds during word building exercises.
For example, have students move up one purple square. Say:
This is the /a/ square. Add a square to show me at.
Students should add a different color square after the purple /a/ square. Say:
. Students should add a different color square before the purple /a/ square.

I thought we could walk to the mall. He will mow the lawn while I talk to Dawn.

Read the title. Explain that this is a poem. Point out that the text is formatted in short lines in groups of four instead of paragraphs. Ask students to listen for words that rhyme, or end with the same sounds.
For the first reading, have students echoread the text with you. Then pair students to reread the poem. Partners can take turns reading each stanza.
Prompt students to find all the words with variant vowel
spellings in the poem and circle them. Then have students chorally read the circled words. Ask students questions about the text to confirm understanding.
Say each word, guide students to write it, then proceed to the next word in the sentence.
Provide supports for words that are completely comprised of the phonics skills students have learned.
These supports include sound boxes, tapping the sounds, and so on.
Provide supports for the high-frequency words students have learned.
When completed, have students read the entire sentence aloud.
Self-Correct: Write the sentences on the board, and have students self-correct. Take note of errors on each students Student Observation Form.
High-Frequency Word Sentences in Writers Notebook
Each week, have students write one sentence for each high-frequency word in a section of a writers notebook.
Then have students read their sentences from the beginning of the year to a partner. This will increase the amount of times they see the word in context, getting to mastery faster.

Write to Deepen Comprehension: Summary and Opinion
Have students draw two columns on a sheet of paper.
Ask them to write one opinion about water use at the top of each column and list reasons and examples from the text below each one.

Then ask them to use this information to write a two or three sentence summary of the selection. Have students share their summaries orally with a partner before writing them to make sure they are clearly stated and brief.
Finally, have students state whether or not they think water should be free for all people and briefly explain why.
Read the title, and have students repeat as they point to each word. Point out that the title asks a question.
Explain that students will read two opinions about this statement: Water should be free for everyone. Ask students to think about which side they agree with.

Explain that a legend is a story from the past that has been passed down over time. It is often about someone who really lived, but the facts of that persons life in the story cant be proven true. Explain that this legend features three birds instead of people: a hawk, a crow, and an eagle. Name and describe each bird and have students point to it in the picture.
